newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: Demonstrators mar French Armistice ceremony.
newsitem.headline: Demonstrators mar French Armistice ceremony.

text.p: Demonstrators protesting against the imprisonment of French Guiana independence leaders disrupted an armistice day ceremony in France's South American territory on Thursday, witnesses said.

More than 100 demonstrators chanting "liberate our comrades," drowned out the music of a French Foreign Legion band playing France's national anthem at the war memorial in French Guiana's capital Cayenne.
There were no reports of violence. War veterans and officials present expressed shock at the protest at the ceremony commemorating the end of World War Two in Europe in 1945.

The demonstrators were protesting the detention of 11 people including 4 leading members of French Guiana's independence movement for allegedly setting fire to the home of French Guiana's state prosecutor during a wave of riots in November.

The arrests triggered a new wave of riots last month as para-military riot police flown in from mainland France clashed in Cayenne for three nights with hooded and armed demonstrators who fired hunting rifles and threw firebombs.
Officials said a total of 11 police have been injured during the unrest, ten by gunfire. One civilian bystander lost an eye when a projectile exploded in his face.
The riots shattered French Guiana's tranquil facade and laid bare economic, political and social woes.

French Guiana is the only non-independent territory on the mainland of the Western Hemisphere. Its economy is heavily dependent on subsidies from France and 23 percent of the population of 150,000 is unemployed.
